Summary:
The patient is a 43-year-old male with a significant medical history of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) following a failed transplant and subsequent nephrectomy. He presented with an episode of narrow complex tachycardia at 3:30 am, which resolved after being given IV metoprolol. He also experienced nausea, for which he was given Zofran, but did not tolerate Kayexalate due to nausea. The renal team is ready to dialize today.

His vital signs include a temperature of 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate ranging from 73 to 155 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 108/76 mmHg to 144/109 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on a nasal cannula. His heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient has a pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology, as evidenced by an echocardiogram. This is a serious condition that can cause decreased cardiac output and hypotension. The differential diagnosis includes uremia, malignant effusion, and infectious/tuberculous effusion. The plan is to follow pulsus, hold ACE inhibitors, continue beta-blockers per home regimen, and perform cardiac catheterization in the morning as per cardiology.

He also has abdominal pain, which is likely referred from pericardial distention. A CT scan did not show an infectious
